Comment: Apparently called the King's Knight opening, but it's still fairly standard.
My standard defense in this situation.
I've never really been a fan of this move.  It seems like putting black just for the sake of saying "check."  While it may weaken the queen side defenses, I like Bc4 instead.
Protect the King and threaten the bishop.
Now he's where he should be.

In hindsight, Be6 was probably a better move.  If he accepts, it's a simple BxB trade, and if he plays 4...Bd5+, I can follow it with 5.c6 and force his bishop back to d3 or farther.  But I guess this was a fine move.
When I saw this move, I was kind of confused.  I've seen (and tried) the queen side fork many times, but this was the first time I've seen it tried king side.
Going to attack the knight.  I don't like it hanging out in such a forward position.
Crap.  I thought that my king had protected f7, but I didn't notice that the bishop was also threatening.  This could've been absolutely disastrous for me.
I felt like I had to save my queen if I wanted any chance to stay in this game.
There goes the rook.  Now he has a great material advantage, and this game could be over fairly quickly.
I decide to get whatever material that I could get at this point.  It also puts my knight into a pretty good position to attack.
Crap, another fork.  Really should've seen this coming...
Saving my queen a second time.  This time, I noticed that his king side was pretty unprotected, so I made a play for a quick mate.  If nothing else, I would at least get the knight.
I guess that he didn't notice the mate looming.  Now he's got a great material advantage, but material isn't everything.

Mate.  This game is good to show the dangers of focusing too much on one or two pieces.  He was able to rack up a great advantage in material, but his defense was non-existent throughout.  I got lucky to win this one, and hopefully I won't get myself into this situation again any time soon.
